predictions: The prime ministers of India and Japan met in Tokyo.

India's new Prime Minister Narendra Modi meets his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe in Tokyo on his first major foreign visit since his election victory in May to discuss economic and security relations.
Mr. Modi is on a five-day trip to Japan to strengthen economic ties with the world's third-largest economy.
Plans for stronger nuclear cooperation are at the top of the agenda.
India also reportedly hopes for a defense cooperation agreement between the two nations.
Karratha police arrest 20-year-old after high-speed motorcycle chase.
A motorcycle was seized after the rider drove it at 125 km/h in a 70 km/h zone and through bushland to escape police in Bilbara.
Traffic police in Karratha attempted to stop a blue motorcycle this morning after observing it leaving a petrol station on Bathdate Road at 125 km/h.
Police report that the driver then ignored stop signals and continued on Burgess Road before turning off into bushland where officers lost sight of it.
The motorcycle, as well as a person matching the driver's description, were later seen at a house on Walcott Way in Bulgarra.
Karratha police have charged a 20-year-old man with failing to stop at a stop sign and reckless driving.
He is supposed to appear before the district court in Karratha on September 23rd.
The motorcycle was seized and impounded for three months.
George Webster charged with hotel rapes in Nairn and Pitlochry.
A man is on trial for the rape of women in two hotels.
The charges against George Webster, 28, were read out at a hearing at the High Court in Glasgow.
He is accused of raping a woman at Scotland's Hotel in Pitlochry, Perthshire, on June 7, 2013.
The charge is that Webster attacked her while she was "unconscious, asleep, and unable to signal consent."
Webster is further accused of raping a second woman at the Golf View Hotel in Nairn in the Scottish Highlands on May 4, 2014.
Judge Lady Rae set the trial date for November 17th at the High Court in Edinburgh.
Return to the very American ideal of labor rights as human rights.
Congressmen Keith Ellison and John Lewis introduced a bill to establish organizing labor unions as a civil right.
"As unions die, so do middle-class jobs," said Ellison, a Minnesota Democrat and co-chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus.
Therefore, I proudly introduce, together with civil rights icon John Lewis, the Employee Empowerment Act.
This groundbreaking law gives workers the same legal options in cases of discrimination due to union organizing as in other forms of discrimination - and thus stops anti-union forces.

The amendment of the national labor law to provide a means for workers subjected to discrimination to organize union representation, to sue for justice in a civil court – and to obtain damages or penalties – is a sensible and necessary initiative.
But it is certainly not a radical initiative - at least not by American standards.
Indeed, the best way to understand what Ellison, Lewis, and the other sponsors of their bill are proposing is to connect it back to a very American idea.

Despite the setbacks that unions have faced in recent years—in Wisconsin, Michigan, and other states across the country—Americans once encouraged countries around the world to recognize, expand, and uphold labor rights.
There was a time, which millions of Americans still remember, when this country mentioned democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press, and the right of association in the same breath.

When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas MacArthur and his staff encouraged the country to adopt a constitution that would ensure that Hideki Tojo's militarized autocracy would be replaced by democracy.

Fully aware that workers and their unions played a role in the creation of a new Japan, they used language that explicitly recognized that "the rights of workers to organize and bargain and act collectively are guaranteed."

When the United States occupied Germany after World War II, General Dwight David Eisenhower and his staff urged the Germans to write a constitution that would ensure that Adolf Hitler's fascism would be replaced by a strong democracy.

In recognition of the fact that workers would need to organize and make their voices heard in the new nation, the Germans included a clause that explicitly stated: "The right to form associations in order to secure and improve working and economic conditions is guaranteed to every individual and to every occupation or trade."
Agreements that restrict this right or aim to diminish it are null and void; measures aimed at doing so are unlawful.

When former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the international human rights commission that drafted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adopted as a global agreement by the United Nations in 1948, Roosevelt and the other drafters included a guarantee that “everyone has the right to form and to join trade unions for the protection of his interests.”
For generations, Americans have accepted the basic premise that labor rights are human rights.

When this country advised other countries on how to form civil and democratic societies, Americans declared that the right to form a union—and for that union to then participate in collective bargaining as an equal partner with businesses and government agencies—must be protected.

After these rights came under attack in America, it is indeed very wise to recall the American ideal, according to which the working population must have the right to organize and make their voices heard in a free and open society.
As Pastor Martin Luther King Jr. said fifty years ago:
History is a great teacher.
Now everyone knows that the labor movement did not restrict the strength of the nation, but increased it.
By raising the standard of living for millions of people, work has miraculously created a market for industry and lifted the entire nation to unimaginable levels of production.
Those who attack the work forget these simple truths, but history preserves them.
History remembers, and so should we.
The formal recognition of labor rights as human rights—and the extension of civil rights protections against discrimination in the formation of worker representation—is long overdue.
Keith Ellison and John Lewis are renewing the ideals that made America great in the past and fulfilled the promise of democracy.
Judge temporarily blocks law that could force all abortion clinics in Louisiana to close.
A US federal judge on Sunday temporarily blocked the implementation of a law in Louisiana that lawyers say would likely have led to the closure of all five of the state's abortion clinics.

This measure, signed into law in June by Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal and scheduled to take effect Sept. 1, would require doctors who perform abortions to obtain admitting privileges at a hospital within 30 miles of their clinic.
The judge's decision, however, means that doctors can provisionally continue to perform abortions legally while they apply for such a right.
"The plaintiffs can continue to work legally while they seek to obtain these rights," wrote U.S. District Judge John deGravelles in his ruling.
A hearing will be scheduled within a month for the judge to make a more permanent decision on the law.
Abortion-rights supporters welcomed the decision, the latest in a series of rulings against similar measures, saying it gives doctors more time to obtain hospital admitting privileges.

"Today's decision means that the women of Louisiana escape an insidious law designed to take away their health and their rights," said Nancy Northup, president and CEO of the Center for Reproductive Rights, which had sued on behalf of three of the state's five clinics to block the law.
It was not immediately clear whether the ruling also applied to the doctors from the two clinics who had not joined the lawsuit and had also applied for admission rights.
Louisiana is one of 11 states that have passed similar laws, with courts recently ruling such measures unconstitutional in Alabama and Mississippi.
Key parts of a Texas law that would have forced most of the state's remaining abortion clinics to close were blocked by a federal judge on Friday.

Abortion rights supporters and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, as well as the American Medical Association, agree that physician referral requirements impose unnecessary restrictions.
Abortion opponents counter that the measures serve to protect women's health, although some also welcomed the impact of clinic closures.
Only one Louisiana abortion provider has patient admitting privileges, the Center for Reproductive Rights said.
If all other doctors in the state are forced to stop performing abortions, this doctor would stop performing the procedure out of fear for his safety, the group said.

In their argument against the ruling, Louisiana state officials said they would not prosecute doctors for performing abortions while their applications for patient transfer privileges were still pending.
Delayed diagnoses and lack of access to the best treatment options lead to higher ovarian cancer death rates in rural areas.
Angelina Jolie and her brother James posted a video tribute online for their mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
Women in rural Australia have a higher risk of dying from ovarian cancer than women in cities.
Researchers analyzed the medical data of more than 1100 Australian women diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005 and found that only 25 percent were still alive five years after diagnosis.

Research leader Susan Jordan from the QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute said the risk of death during the study was 20 percent higher for those living in rural and remote areas of the state compared to those in urban areas.
SMALL STUDY: New drugs could slow lung and ovarian cancer.
The researchers investigated the medical care of the women over seven years.
Dr. Jordan said that a woman's age at diagnosis, the type of ovarian cancer, existing pre-existing conditions, as well as social and economic status, also influenced the chances of survival.
For older women and those whose cancer was already more advanced at the time of diagnosis, the survival rate was lowest.
For those who lived in rural and remote regions of the state, the mortality risk was 20 percent higher during the study than for those in urban areas.

Although the study did not investigate why women living outside the city were more likely to die from ovarian cancer, Dr. Jordan suggests delayed diagnosis and lack of access to the best treatment centers as possible factors.
"This disease is best treated by gynecological oncologists, and these are mostly found in larger cities," she said.

Despite the improvement of telemedicine services to counteract distances, she proposed as a possible remedy an increase in the service of flown-in doctors to give specialists the opportunity to care for women closer to their homes, as well as treatment programs for people outside their region.

Dr. Jordan said that the study revealed a poor long-term survival rate for women with ovarian cancer, regardless of geographical status, and highlighted the need for better treatment and prevention strategies.
The Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer Cancer-funded study is published today in the Medical Journal of Australia.
In March 2013, Elisha Neave, a 33-year-old young mother from the Gold Coast, learned that she had an aggressive form of ovarian cancer.
Garden centers regret declining homeowner numbers.

The decline, coupled with a heightened drop in the number of homeowners under 35, could lead garden centres to lose tens of thousands of pounds a year when today's young consumers reach the "core age group for garden products", according to an HTA study reported in the Financial Times.
The report states that renters spend on average 55 percent of the amount that homeowners spend on their gardens.

The rise in people living in highly urbanized areas without gardens, the popular practice of paving over front gardens for parking, and the decreasing size of gardens are further factors threatening the industry, which has estimated annual sales of £5 billion.
In Greater London, where homeownership has fallen from 61 to 43 percent over a period of 6 years, the lowest spending on garden products per household is reported.
The HTA and the Royal Horticultural Society point out that renting or having small gardens doesn't mean that people can't grow plants.
Guy Barter, chief horticultural advisor for the RHS, said: "Container gardening is very popular with renters, for example, because they can take their plants with them when they move."
The HTA report identified the period between 1997 and 2005 as the "golden age" of garden retailing due to rising homeownership and economic prosperity from the late 1980s to the mid-1990s.
He also predicted an improved market situation for this year due to better weather following unfavorable weather conditions in March and April of last year.
The protest movement in Pakistan, led by opposition politician Imran Khan and cleric Tahirul Qadri, continues.
In the capital Islamabad, around 1000 demonstrators stormed the state television broadcaster PTV.
Information Minister Pervaiz Rashid said soldiers were able to push the protesters out of the PTV building again.
The station ceased broadcasting for about 40 minutes, but is now transmitting again.
At the same time, around 3,000 demonstrators tried to reach the residence of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif.
About a kilometer away, equipped with sticks and stones, they clashed with security forces.
The police used tear gas.
The demonstrators demanded Sharif's resignation, but he rejects this.
Meanwhile, the country's army is urging a political solution to the conflict, "without wasting time and without using violence".
After a meeting at headquarters on Sunday evening, the military announced: "The army remains committed to its role of ensuring the security of the state."
The military plays an important role in Pakistan and has frequently staged coups.
Opposition politician Imran Khan accuses Prime Minister Sharif of cheating in the parliamentary election last May.
The protests escalated over the weekend after Khan and Qadri called on their supporters to advance on Sharif's residence.
Three people had been killed in the process.
Turkey summons US diplomat over espionage report.
The Turkish Foreign Ministry summoned the most senior US diplomat in the country to provide information on a report about American and British espionage in Turkey.
Deputy Prime Minister Bülent said that the US Embassy chargé d'affaires and Turkish officials had discussed the report on Monday.

The German magazine Der Spiegel, as well as the online magazine The Intercept, reported that the documents leaked by former US National Security Agency analyst Edward Snowden show that Turkey was a main area of operations for US and British intelligence agencies.
According to Turkish news agencies, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan downplayed the importance of the report and said that all important countries spy on each other.
A previous report that Germany's most important intelligence agency also had Ankara in its sights caused significantly more annoyed reactions from the Turkish government.
Warning strike: Train drivers threaten consequences for commuters.
The nationwide train drivers' strike on Monday evening could also affect passenger transport in NRW.
The strike announced for 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. will affect all transport companies nationwide, including long-distance, regional and suburban rail services.
The main focus of the warning strike is freight transport.
Photo: A. Burgi/Archive.
said the district chairman of the German Train Drivers' Union (GDL), Sven Schmitte, in Düsseldorf.
We expect significant losses.
There are no regional focuses.
The main focus of the warning strike is freight transport.
Deutsche Bahn in NRW announced it would do everything to minimize the impact.
However, the GDL has not said where it intends to strike, so it is difficult to predict the consequences concretely.
Magaluf police chief accused of corruption.
Prosecutors presented evidence of extortion by police officers and Calvià town employees to the Mallorca prosecutor's office on Friday.
The chief of police of Calvià on the holiday island of Mallorca has been arrested following corruption allegations from business owners and bar owners in the notorious binge-drinking hotspot Magaluf.

Chief Inspector José Antonio Navarro has been remanded in custody following corruption allegations made against him by several businesspeople from Punta Ballena, the street where most of Magaluf's bars and nightclubs are located.

According to the online daily newspaper Mallorca Diario, prosecutors presented evidence of extortion by police officers and Calvià city employees to Mallorca's Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office on Friday.
Two more local police officers were arrested by the Spanish Guardia Civil in connection with the corruption allegations and are being questioned by a judge along with Navarro.
The national Spanish daily newspaper ABC reported that the disgruntled nightclub owners testified that cronyism within the authorities was having a serious impact on their businesses.
"It's no longer about making money, it's about survival," one of the businessmen told the court.
Leave our livelihoods out of the game. / Don't gamble with our livelihoods.
We have nothing to lose.
Magaluf made international headlines this summer due to a viral YouTube video showing an 18-year-old British tourist performing fellatio on 24 men during a pub crawl.
The island authorities have since tried to stop the disorderly conduct of intoxicated holidaymakers in Magaluf by minimizing the number of participants in the notorious alcohol-fueled pub crawls.
The Playhouse Club, where the fellatio incident took place, was forced to close for a year, while Playhouse and the pub crawl organizer Carnage have to pay a combined fine of €55,000 ($73,000).

The tourist resort of Magaluf, which is particularly popular with young British holidaymakers, is also known for numerous alcohol-related accidents, including the trend of "balconing", where people jump from one balcony to another or from a balcony into the hotel pool.
The first day of spring with wet and stormy weather conditions is affecting flights from Adelaide Airport.
Spring has brought a wintry surprise to South Australia, with heavy showers and strong winds disrupting flights from Adelaide Airport.
In the evening, until 9 pm, a further 5mm of rain fell on the city, after 6.6mm which had already fallen during the night leading up to Sunday.
The last precipitation was the result of a series of short, stormy showers, including a downpour that started shortly before 8 pm and delivered almost 4mm of rainfall in about 10 minutes.
After last week's early dose of spring, temperatures in the city fell back to a high of just 15.8°C on Monday.
The gusty weather conditions likely caused the delayed landing of a Virgin Airlines flight from Melbourne to Adelaide.
The plane was supposed to land shortly after 7:30 p.m., but was hit by wind shear—a sudden change in wind speed or direction over a short distance—and had to abort the landing.
Wind gusts reached about 50 km/h on the ground at Adelaide Airport at this time.
The flight data showed that the aircraft had to abort a second landing attempt and finally touched down around 8:40 PM.
The flight delay subsequently led to the delay of several other flights, including an Emirates flight from Dubai and a Qantas flight from Sydney.
A high of 16°C is forecast for Adelaide on Tuesday, with possible showers.
Matthies thinks: High time for major networking.

In view of the galloping technological progress that threatens to transform our cozy homes into high-tech control centers, our columnist Bernd Matthies consoles himself with a very familiar electronic accessory.
As I'm writing this, my gaze falls on the spiral cord connecting the receiver to the telephone, and I think: Wow, how retro is that?
But there's a thought behind it: If it weren't for the cable, all the handsets would be flying around the house ownerless in no time, and that would be considerably more retro.
Anyway, it applies to the electronic (electronic?)...
No, typo: electronic) sector the rule that today's world novelty is tomorrow's e-waste, bought - obsolete..
And whoever, for example, still has a tube television in their living room today, is simply saying that they fundamentally reject television.
Why these considerations?
Because the crowding of the IFA at the Funkturm this week again highlights our absolute incompetence in matters of electronics...

The layperson, who once mastered the washing machine and CD player without a second thought, today doesn't even grasp the purpose of the devices spread out before them with incomprehensibly vain expert jargon: "Connected Home, Wearables, Health Care and Urban Technologies," the press office promises us.
Are you kidding me?
What is there to talk about with people who apparently willingly spread such nonsense?
Basically, for about 20 years, it's been all about us supposedly needing to network our homes.
So that the yogurt reorders itself, so that the smoke detector tells us while we're on vacation in the Maldives that the study is on fire...
And wouldn't it be wonderful if we could turn on the air conditioning from the office for our imminent arrival...?
Yes, that does require air conditioning, however.
But one dream will definitely come true soon: We lift our wristwatch, tell it loudly "Vacuum!" - and at home the robot vacuum cleaner starts up.
Crazy.. / Insane..

Everything is leading to nothing less than a revolution: "The lines between white goods and brown goods are blurring," whispers an industry insider. You can connect the washing machine to headphones, the steam cooker sends the weather report, and the data glasses show how much longer the pizza needs in the oven, which is useless, however, because we're stuck in traffic.
From daily experience we also know: If a newfangled gadget is really urgently needed, the battery is guaranteed to be dead.
Which is another reason why the spiral cord on the telephone will also survive the next radio exhibitions.
Israeli children return to their schools after the war in Gaza.

Thousands of Israeli children from areas near the Gaza Strip returned to school on Monday after spending the summer in bomb shelters as rocket and mortar fire rained down on their communities during the 50-day war between Israel and Hamas, and schools in Gaza remained closed as the territory recovered from the fighting.
The start of the school year brought a sense of joy and anticipation to the rocket-scarred communities in southern Israel, but the signs of the fighting are still fresh.
In the southern city of Ashdod, staff at the "Pashosh" kindergarten, which was hit by a rocket, removed shrapnel from the walls and sliding doors before the students arrived.
"We're a little scared, but excited," said Ronit Bart, a resident of Kibbutz Saad and an English teacher there.
Many children from our area urgently need the return to a routine.
Her 11-year-old daughter Shani Bart said it felt "a bit strange" to suddenly go back to school.
"Those were difficult times, and we didn't leave the house at all," she said.
President Reuven Rivlin visited the kibbutz near the Gaza border to offer his support.

Until a ceasefire interrupted the war last week, thousands of residents of border communities like Saad remained in their homes or left their homes to move to safer areas further away from Gaza and escape the rocket and mortar fire.
Many residents of Nahal Oz, a community near the Gaza border where a 4-year-old boy was killed by a Palestinian mortar shell, are still hesitant to return.
The Ministry of Education announced that about a dozen families had not yet returned.
Your children have been temporarily placed in other schools.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited a school in Sderot, a border town near Gaza, which has been heavily affected by Palestinian shelling.
He appealed to the children to learn a lot and said, "We will ensure that you acquire knowledge and offer you security."
Israel and Hamas agreed on an indefinite ceasefire last Tuesday.

The ceasefire brought an immediate end to the fighting; however, key issues remain unresolved, such as Hamas's demand for a lifting of the Israeli-Egyptian blockade of Gaza and the reopening of Gaza's air and seaports.
Israel demands the disarmament of Hamas and the return of the bodies of two Israeli soldiers killed in the fighting.
A new round of indirect talks is expected to begin in Egypt later this month.
In the war, more than 2,100 Palestinians were killed, three-quarters of them civilians, and at least 494 children according to Palestinian and UN estimates.
Israel disputes these figures and estimates that at least half of those killed were combatants, but did not provide concrete evidence for this information.
On the Israeli side, 66 soldiers and six civilians, including a Thai worker, were killed.
Hamas and other fighters in Gaza fired 4,591 rockets and mortar shells at Israeli cities during the fighting, most of them in the south of the country.
Meanwhile, the Israeli military carried out more than 5,000 air and other attacks.
The Israeli attacks damaged or destroyed thousands of homes in the Gaza Strip, and about 250,000 people sought refuge in more than 100 UN schools that were converted into temporary shelters.
While tens of thousands of people continue to live in shelters and the fighting continues, education authorities postponed the start of the school year last week.
"I hope school will reopen soon so we can continue learning, like the children in the world and the Jewish children," said Mohammad Amara, a 13-year-old boy currently living in a school in Gaza City.
After the election in Saxony: CDU Vice-Chairman Strobl questions NPD ban proceedings.
In light of the NPD's losses in the Saxony elections, CDU Vice Chairman Thomas Strobl has called for an end to the ongoing NPD ban proceedings before the Federal Constitutional Court.
Berlin - According to CDU Vice Chairman Thomas Strobl, the ongoing ban proceedings against the NPD before the Federal Constitutional Court should end.
"The NPD performed worse than last time," Strobl, who is also the CDU state chairman in Baden-Württemberg, told the "Leipziger Volkszeitung".
This is a welcome development in the right direction and a development that makes me more likely to conclude that the NPD should be fought politically and not before the Constitutional Court.
The NPD narrowly failed to reach the five percent hurdle in Sunday's vote.
A first attempt to ban the far-right party failed in 2003 because the Office for the Protection of the Constitution had informants even in the NPD leadership at the time.
In December 2013, the Bundesrat submitted a new motion in Karlsruhe after long preparation.
The Federal Government and the Bundestag did not join.
Harburg: Tents for new refugees.
At Neuländer Platz, refugees are now being housed in tents.
The central initial reception center for refugees in Harburg is bursting at the seams.
Now the Interior Ministry has had three Red Cross tents set up next to it.
The district politicians were only informed shortly beforehand - they are not very enthusiastic.

"These rushed actions further fuel reservations among citizens and don't give district politicians the opportunity to constructively participate in the humane accommodation of refugees," says, for example, Britta Herrmann, parliamentary group leader of the Greens in the Harburg district assembly.
Their party demands that the Harburg district administration make currently unused houses available for accommodation.
96 refugees can be accommodated in the three tents.
Reasons for overcrowding in the initial reception centers are the influx of people seeking help - and the fact that the authorities cannot provide enough places in subsequent facilities.
Many refugees therefore stay longer than the regular three months.
House prices have seen their strongest winter rise in seven years, a widely watched index shows.
The RP Data CoreLogic Hedonic Home Value Index for detached houses in the Australian capital rose 1.1 percent in August, RP Data said Monday.
Due to this increase, the total increase in June, July, and August is 4.2 percent, the largest increase in the winter months since 2007.
The annual price increase was 10.9 percent, more than double the increase in the 12 months to August 2013, but the increases were not evenly distributed across the country.
RP Data's head of research, Tim Lawless, said that Sydney and Melbourne are driving a two-tiered market.
RP Data figures show that house prices rose by 16.1 percent in Sydney last year, compared to 11.7 percent in Melbourne.
The following markets are Adelaide, Brisbane, and Darwin, where prices rose by an average of five and six percent.
At the other end of the scale is Canberra, which was hit hard by cuts in government spending and where prices rose by only 1.4 percent over the year.
Mr. Lawless went on to say that with the beginning of spring, an increase in properties for sale would be observed over the next few months, which would subject the market "to a real test".

"Considering the continuing high rate of auction prices, a generally fast sales rate, and the persistently low interest rate environment, it is likely that home prices will continue to rise over the next three months," he said.
In a statement to the Neue Presse, he contradicts statements made by managing director Peer Medau and accuses him of posturing "like a general."
This is not the university's style, the statement says.
The Medau family had already been "informed verbally of the university's request in mid-June".
The statement that the plans only became known in July is definitely false," said Pötzl.
At the same time, he points out that the plans are not "predeterminations or even decisions," but that there are "preferences."
The necessary widening of the narrow road up to the castle for access is also less dramatic than the Medaus feared.
There was and is no talk of a nine-meter-wide road.
"It's currently about 5.50 meters, which is one meter wider than before," explains Pötzl.
Pötzl does not accept the Medau operators' argument that their free, school-owned parking spaces will in future only be used by university students.
Parking is not an issue at all, because, like other public parking lots, it can now be solved intelligently.
Think of the residents.
The Bergwichtel daycare center, which is located on the site and in front of which the access road to the parking garage would run, should not be affected, according to the university president.

Rather, he points out "that it's not just about the daycare center, but also about the residents at the intersection with Friedrich-Streib-Straße and the 800 students of the neighboring secondary school.
"So it's about much more than the vested interests of Messrs. Medau," said Pötzl.

Whether the criticism of the parents' council of the daycare center, that with the expansion of the road "one of Coburg's few natural spots would be lost," is justified, "the reader can decide for themselves."

At the beginning of October, Pötzl, together with the Bamberg State Construction Office, wants to inform the city councilors about the structural development of the university until 2020 "and in this context address the importance of the new access".
Peer Medau informed the parents of the daycare center about the university's plans last week.
Accordingly, access to the new parking garage will not be via the campus and Friedrich-Streib-Straße as before, but via Medau-Berg.
This would require the narrow road to be widened to two lanes for about one kilometer.
According to Medaus' projections, traffic in the park of Hohenfels Castle would increase tenfold.
There is talk of about 2000 vehicles daily.
The city has so far declined to comment on the project.
Glandorf retires from the handball national team.
Holger Glandorf will no longer play for the DHB team.
The 31-year-old from Bundesliga club SG Flensburg-Handewitt cited health problems as the main reason for this decision.
The decision wasn't easy for me; it matured over several months.
"It is time for me to listen to my body's signals and end my career in the national team," the 2007 world champion announced on his Facebook page.
He thus retires from international football with a record of 167 caps and 576 goals for Germany.

Because the powerful backcourt player wants to continue scoring goals for the Champions League winner from Flensburg for a few more years, he is no longer available to the new national coach Dagur Sigurdsson.
With the Icelander, who will announce his squad for the international matches against Switzerland on Tuesday, Glandorf had a "long and good conversation".
His ideas and approaches have inspired me just as they will inspire my long-time teammates and my successors.
But for my club I also want to be available and healthy in the coming years, and for that, longer recovery breaks are necessary, which the current double burden doesn't allow.
The left-hander had even feared the end of his career in 2012 after a heel infection.
Due to Achilles tendon problems, he had been treated by team doctors of the German Handball Federation (DHB) with a cortisone injection, which later triggered a severe inflammation.
An emergency operation and two further procedures followed.
Then Glandorf announced a lawsuit against the team doctor, the dispute ended with a settlement.
Twelve years of professional and eleven years of national team career don't leave any body unmarked.
I have some health issues that I can no longer ignore.
After the three infection-related foot surgeries, which took place in quick succession in 2012, I never really got my blood pressure under control.
To this are added some other wear-related complaints/issues.
"Already at the beginning of the year, I realized that I can control my head, but I can't fool my body," Glandorf explained in an interview with the magazine "Handball Time".
He would only be available for a comeback in an absolute emergency.
"If all else fails, I'm always willing to talk," the father of two explained to the trade magazine.
However, I can count the years I can still play handball on one hand.
I also have to say that after my long hospital stay in 2012, I've become quite humble regarding my health.
After my career, I'd like to at least be able to walk reasonably straight.
Besides the World Championship title in 2007 and winning the Champions League in 2014, he won the EHF Cup in 2008 (with HSG Nordhorn) and 2010 (with TBV Lemgo).
In 2012, he also secured the European Cup Winners' Cup with Flensburg.
German economy shrank by 0.2 percent in spring.
The crises around the globe slowed the German economy in the second quarter.
Gross domestic product fell by 0.2 percent from April to the end of June 2014 compared to the previous quarter.
The Federal Statistical Office announced this, confirming preliminary calculations.
Only consumption stimulated the economy in spring, while investments declined.
Foreign trade also slowed the economy.
Thanks to the strong start to the year, GDP grew by a total of 0.8 percent in the first half of the year compared to the second half of 2013.
Horstmar was the starting point and the destination of the "Münsterland-Mooiste", which led through the fortified town for the first time on Sunday.
The fortified town of Horstmar experienced an invasion of Dutch cyclists on Sunday.
The largest cycling association in the Netherlands, NTFU, organized the so-called "Münsterland-Mooiste" (Münsterland's Most Beautiful).
This is the largest cycling tour across Münsterland, the cycling paradise near the Netherlands.
Over 1000 participants thanked Jos ter Huerne for organizing this tour through Münsterland by registering.
This tour was offered to interested parties through advertisements in various trade journals.
We come from Den Helder and drove overnight to participate in this tour.
"We'd like to get to know the Münsterland region better this way, too," the cyclists enthused about the route through the districts of Steinfurt, Borken, and Coesfeld.
After registering at the clubhouse of the Sta.. shooting club
Katharina went on a little "peace ride" through the city over the wall, where it also started.
The route, which was offered for three different categories, continued towards Herrenholz via Schöppinger Berg in the direction of Coesfeld and via Havixbeck and Billerbeck back to Horstmar.

On routes of 95 kilometers with 1175 meters of elevation gain, 120 kilometers with 1475 meters of elevation gain, and 145 kilometers with 1775 meters of elevation gain, the cyclists proved their good fitness.
They were provided with food/refreshments in Havixbeck and Billerbeck along the way.
Main organizer Jos ter Huerne and deputy mayor Heinz Lölfing were very pleased with the success of this cycling event.
We are satisfied and it was a nice experience for everyone involved.
"The organization went smoothly and there were no negative incidents," Heinz Lölfing concludes positively about this event.
Unfortunately, not as many participants came as the organizer had hoped, probably due to the bad weather forecast and the morning rain.

Konstantin Wecker's relentlessly honest memoirs.

It's actually more of a philosophical testament than a biography that Konstantin Wecker, singer-songwriter, pacifist, political activist, ex-convict, has put to paper in 287 pages of "Monk and Warrior".
Not chronologically, but rather thought fragment for thought fragment, the Munich native, born on June 1, 1947, wrote down his memoirs, each chapter introduced by a fitting song lyric.
And he is relentlessly honest about it: From masturbation as a high school student to shoplifting and drug use, he leaves no human weakness out.
Also, to show how he himself learned tolerance in dealing with his fellow human beings.

Abstract, but all the more important concepts also occupy a large space: love, soul, ego, being in the present, spirituality - he tries to get to the bottom of all of this, in a very philosophical, but also very personal way.

And he also explains his pacifism, his social criticism, his political engagement - and also how not only music shaped him (the opera lover became a soul and rock musician), but also his imprisonment.
The latter has also brought the bon vivant Konstantin Wecker closer to the ascetic monk, which "arises through subtraction," as he says, "by omitting everything unnecessary."
Amidst all the high-minded views, there are also short, down-to-earth anecdotes: for example, about brawls in a bar frequented by GIs, or a crazy car ride where he aimed straight for a tree.
Even there he is relentlessly honest.
Lenny Henry: My father never hugged me.
Never said "I love you".
Henry was one of seven children in a family of Jamaican immigrants in Dudley in the Midlands in 1958.
His father, who died when Henry was 19, worked in a factory and their relationship was limited.
Henry is rehearsing for a comedy, Rudy's Rare Records, which is partly based on an imaginary conversation with his father and originated from the series on Radio 4.
The soundtrack is a mix of reggae and rap, with lively melodies.
But Henry had to work through some difficult childhood moments.
He attended many therapies after his mother's death, and Henry is reflective about his relationship with his father.
It was hard to know him.
One never saw his face, only heard his voice: "Stop with the noise..."
Leave your sister alone.
Move!
I want to watch cricket.

My older brothers Seymour and Hilton - who were already grown up when I was a child - went to the pub with him and talked about things like the shape of the beer glass or the beauty of a cricket stroke.
I never had such a conversation with him.
For a large part of his life, he was that serious guy in the corner reading the newspaper.
Henry recently opened a foundry in Dudley, and although the conditions are better than in his father's time, he gained an insight into what life might have been like for him.
It is somewhat brighter now, but they are dark, smoky, deep Stygian labyrinths with bursts of flame and smoke and much soot.
My father used to just lie down in the tub and then you could slowly hear him start to sing, because he could wash the foundry off of himself.
As I walked around there, I realized he'd been doing that for years to put food on the table, and my respect for him grew.
Nevertheless, Henry grew up as a child without expressions of love from his parents.
My father never hugged me, he never said "I love you".
Only when my mother was nearing the end of her life did we start saying, "I love you, I love you, I love you."
Through his own daughter, Billie, with Dawn French, he was able to share the love he had missed as a child.
Could you stop with the "I love you"?
Stop hugging me!
Dad, I'm 22!
with Dawn French
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She is a great mother.
He/She is still friends with French, to whom he/she was married for 25 years.
Dawn is a good person.
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She is a great mother.
Henry's own mother was diabetic.
That contributed to her death.
So when I became very, very overweight and showed symptoms of diabetes, my doctor said "You have to be radical..."
So I went through with this fitness thing and also had to do a drastic diet to reverse the symptoms.
It is very difficult.
And it is exhausting.
Nobody likes eating carrots.
Henry's career change might be reflected in his elegant, closely trimmed beard.
Since he was praised by the critics for his Othello, he has been consumed by the theater.
The Comedy of Errors followed, and then Fences by August Wilson.
That's a different experience than the sitcoms and comedies that filled his busy work life.
He started at just 16 years old, when he was working in a factory.
A DJ discovered him on stage while he was imitating people and wrote to New Faces about him.
His television career began in the mid-seventies. "I was the only Black impersonator/comedian on television for quite a long time."
He learned on the job.
Not only did I have to grow up in the public eye, but from 1975 to 1985 I also had to learn how to become an efficient joke-telling machine while being a TV star, and that was really difficult.
Lenny 1975 on New Faces.
Because his manager owned the stage rights to the Black and White Minstrel Show, a light entertainment program in which people "blacked up," Henry performed his comedy there for over five years.
My family was very uncomfortable with that.
I somehow wish it had never happened, but I don't regret doing it.
It was a strange, unpleasant position for me, but I worked on huge projects and learned how to deal with a large audience.
But this "years-long, award-winning, light pillar of British television" was also a "grotesque parody of Black people."
By introducing characters that both mocked and celebrated British Black culture, Henry worked in an alternative comedy circuit in the eighties.
The first series of The Lenny Henry Show aired in 1984, and in the nineties he was known for, among other things, playing the chef Gareth Blacklock in the comedy series Chef!.

Advertising, documentaries, TV series and film roles shaped his next decade, but after his BBC series LennyHenry.tv in 2008, he thought: "What are you doing next, Len, because it all feels like you're just killing time or treading water a bit?".
Then came a documentary series for Radio 4 titled What's So Great About...?
The first episode revolved around Shakespeare.

Everyone we interviewed for the show, Peter Hall, Trevor Nunn, Adrian Lester, Judi Dench, said "You should give it a try."
Don't act like you know what you're talking about if you don't.

Henry performed 20 lines from Othello's last speech for the documentary and he was thrilled.
I had the feeling that I could do it.
It was almost as if someone had finally put my head on straight.
That's what it's about, it's a serious matter, take it seriously, learn your lines, do some research.
The rehearsals were brutal, and I read this play for months before we did it.
And it was a success.
They seemed to be expecting a car accident, and it just didn't happen.
And soon he appeared in the Comedy of Errors.
Suddenly I was in the National Theatre and I could hardly believe it.
There was a moment when I thought, "Oh, you've changed."

I am not responsible.

You're acting in a play, so stay in character.

I ask him if he will ever do another stand-up comedy tour.

Houthi rebels block roads in Yemen's capital.
In the conflict between Shiite Houthi rebels and the Yemeni government, the Houthis have called for civil disobedience in the capital Sanaa.
Huthi supporters reportedly occupied central streets in Sanaa on Monday, a spokesman for the Huthi party "Ansar Allah" said.
Access to the parliament was also blocked.
Yemeni media report traffic chaos in the capital.
According to the online edition of the newspaper "Yemen Post", Houthi leader Abdulmalik al-Houthi called for the measures on Sunday evening.
According to the paper, Houthi threatened further escalation of the conflict if his demands were not met.
The Shiite Houthis are fighting for more independence from the Sunni-ruled Yemen and are demanding the resignation of the government.
The Houthi tribe has been besieging the Yemeni capital for almost two weeks.
Around 30,000 rebels have set up protest camps on the main access roads to Sanaa.
In the surrounding area, bloody battles with the Yemeni army repeatedly occur.
Kenya registers civil servants to curb "ghost workers".
Kenya has begun biometrically registering all civil servants to remove "ghost workers" from government payrolls.
Employees who do not register within the next two weeks would no longer be paid, according to a government announcement.
The government suspects that thousands of people are still receiving salary payments even after leaving public service.
President Uhuru Kenyatta promised to fight corruption in the public service when he took office in 2013.
An audit earlier this year found that at least $1 million (£700,000) per month was being lost in payments to "ghost workers" and through other fraudulent financial practices.
The government suspects that salaries continue to be paid into accounts after a person has died or left public service, Wanyama Chebusiri reports for the BBC from the capital Nairobi.
All officials must now appear at identification centers within the next two weeks to ensure their data is recorded via biometric registration, a government message said.
Anyone who did this without a credible excuse would be removed from the payroll, the message continued.

"This process will significantly contribute to streamlining the public service by establishing the actual number of civil servants and cleaning up the payroll at both levels of government – thus eliminating "ghost workers"," said Anne Waiguru, the Cabinet Secretary in the Ministry of Devolution and Planning.
The scandal surrounding art advisor Helge Achenbach will be heard in court for the first time on November 11.

Five heirs of Berthold Albrecht, son of Aldi founder Theo Albrecht, are demanding 19.4 million euros in damages in a civil lawsuit at the Düsseldorf Regional Court from Achenbach and two of his companies, which are in insolvency proceedings.
A court spokeswoman announced this on Monday.
The lawsuit alleges that Achenbach defrauded Berthold Albrecht when purchasing artwork and classic cars, charging him higher prices than were actually paid.
This also resulted in a higher commission than agreed.
Achenbach bought valuables worth 121 million euros for Albrecht.
Children need roots and wings.
He was in the school service for 44 years, 23 of which as headmaster/principal.
From this time, Manfred Richter knows many established Petershausen and Kollbach residents from their time as students.
His methods were sometimes unconventional, but always driven by his desire to see the human in the student.
Sněžka (or Schneekoppe) is the most famous mountain in the Giant Mountains (or Krkonoše).
Manfred Richter loves the painting with the motif from his homeland.
Richter was born in 1930 in Trautenau, North Bohemia, now Trutnov.
Already at 14, after four years of secondary school, he was interested in the teaching profession.
One year later, the Sudeten Germans were expropriated.
Within half an hour, the family had to leave their house.
After a few months in a camp, it went to Bavaria in 1946 - in a freight car.
So Richter ended up in Senkendorf, Upper Franconia.
Teacher training took place in Bamberg.

For this, Manfred Richter had to walk ten kilometers to the nearest train station six times a week, take the train to Bamberg, then walk three kilometers across the entire city to school, and back again in the evening.
After two months, Manfred Richter got a place to sleep in a Red Cross shelter in Bamberg: together with up to 15 classmates in a dormitory.
In 1951 he took the first state examination and in 1954, after three years as a student teacher, the second.
Since Upper Franconia had no open teaching position for him, he applied to Upper Bavaria and arrived at the school in Kollbach on November 1, 1954.
The "maid's room" was his first "staff apartment" in the school building.
In 1958, he moved into a three-room staff apartment in the newly built teachers' residence next to the school.
Manfred Richter bought this house in 1980, after the school in Kollbach had been closed in 1968.
Until then, there were three classes in Kollbach in the Petershausen-Kollbach school district and five in Petershausen.
From the school year 1968/69, these were combined in Petershausen in what is now the town hall.
When the Indersdorf school district was founded, only the elementary school remained in town.
To avoid a demotion in the now smaller school, the then headmaster Georg Sigl transferred to Karlsfeld - and Manfred Richter became his successor.
But Petershausen grew, and so the children and their teachers were able to move into the current building in September 1982, which was expanded in 1997 after Richter's retirement.

Manfred Richter praises the uncomplicated generosity of the then mayor Ludwig Götz, who, at the municipality's expense, had an additional workshop built and, during the expansion in 1997, cellar rooms, even though this was not eligible for subsidies according to the guidelines for school buildings.
"Mayor Götz was very supportive of schools," Richter recalled gratefully.

Throughout his entire career, Manfred Richter never forgot the comment of a government official, who, in response to a presentation by a school superintendent about law and justice, had said: "One must never forget love." Manfred Richter implemented what he had heard there as a young teacher.
"You have to give children two things: roots and wings," says the now 84-year-old.
And he had to learn: "That doesn't always work out." Whether he meant only his students or equally his own six children, isn't entirely clear.
In any case, Richter's actions were sometimes unconventional.
If students fought, they didn't get detention from him, nor were they made to stay after school.
At the municipality's expense, Richter had purchased two pairs of boxing gloves and had the two rivals fight each other, even if it meant a black eye or two.
For the benefit of the school, Richter, as headmaster, maintained a good relationship with the then-mayor Ludwig Götz (CSU).
This motivated the non-partisan judge, after his retirement, to at least run as the last candidate on the CSU party list for the local council in 1996.
But Richter was pre-selected for sixth place and joined the CSU.

HR4 bike tour: 700 cyclists make stops in the spa gardens of Bad Salzhausen and Schotten.
When cyclists take a break on their tour in Bad Salzhausen or Schotten, that in itself is nothing special.

On Friday, however, the sheer number of those taking a break was impressive: The 700 participants of the hr4 bike tour, along with their accompanying support crew, enjoyed a break in the lower spa gardens of Bad Salzhausen and later an open-air party in the Alteburgpark in Schotten.
Under the motto "Cycling and celebrating on newly discovered paths between Nidda and Kinzig", the participants met on Thursday in Bad Vilbel and experienced a concert by Van Baker & Band there.
On Friday things got serious: The cyclists tackled the first stage, the 60 kilometers via Florstadt to Bad Salzhausen and on to Schotten.
In Bad Salzhausen, the athletes were welcomed by Mayor Hans-Peter Seum, who had started the bike ride in Bad Vilbel, and Petra Schwing-Döring, the director of the Bad Salzhausen municipal enterprise.

For the refreshment of body and mind, all sorts of good things had been prepared: The countrywomen from Ranstadt and Nieder-Mockstadt had baked 85 trays of apple, plum, crumble, and cheesecake, which the energetic cyclists thoroughly enjoyed.
"Only country women can bake cakes like this," praised a participant from Aulendiebach, while ordering another piece.
Cold refreshments could be purchased at the Geiß-Nidda Gymnastics Club's drink stand.
The "Duo Bravo" entertained the visitors with well-known melodies from operettas and musicals and received enthusiastic applause.
The beautiful ambiance of the park had a relaxing effect.
A gentleman was also enjoying a head massage from his partner: "He's earned it, after all, he's already fixed some broken bicycle chains today."

Meanwhile, the mayor and the plant manager still had to work: They were interviewed at the fountain in front of the spa house by reporter Rainer Janke and used the opportunity to promote Bad Salzhausen on the radio.
Even head of promotions Tobias Hagen, who has been the tour guide since the first hr4 bike tour in 2004, could only catch his breath briefly, as he had plenty to do with the on-site technology.

His pickup truck, in which he communicated with his employees and the 15-member motorcycle escort of the Hessian police via three phones and a radio, wrote Facebook posts, and made reports, also needed a check.

"The majority of the participants come from the Rhine-Main area," he said, "but also from Giessen or Fulda, from Lauterbach or the Taunus, and even from numerous cities in Westphalia cyclists have travelled here."
The number of participants depends somewhat on the available accommodation capacity.
In Category I, participants will be accommodated in hotels, in Category II in shared accommodation.
The cyclists had a good impression of the spa town when they set off again after an hour and a half: "Goodbye!".
"It was lovely in Bad Salzhausen!" they waved goodbye.
After arriving in Schotten, the group was allowed a short breather.
But in the evening, the cyclists were challenged in the idyllic Alteburgpark.

Under the direction of the Schotten Society for Tourism and City Marketing (GTS), the park had been given a lovely festive atmosphere and, of course, treats, such as tarte flambée with well-chilled Federweißer (partially fermented wine), had been prepared.
Mayor Susanne Schaab, GTS Managing Director Markus Hoßfeld, and MSC Chairman Wolfgang Wagner-Sachs, in his role as board member of ADAC Hessen-Thüringen, welcomed the visitors.
The three were visibly pleased about the "hustle and bustle in Schotten".
DJ Tobias Hagen then opened the dance floor.
The opportunity to move energetically outdoors was eagerly seized, despite the physical activity already undertaken while cycling.
Among the guests were an increasing number of locals, who were just as taken with the good atmosphere as the large group of cyclists.
On the second day, the cyclists' itinerary included the towns of Birstein, Wächtersbach, and Bad Orb - including a concert with the Trenkwalder music group.
Yesterday, after cycling 180 kilometers, the athletes arrived back in Bad Vilbel.
Dozens of Turkish police officers arrested for "conspiracy" against the government.
A total of 33 police officers have been arrested in Turkey on suspicion of "conspiracy against the government," local media agencies report.
The police authorities gave no immediate comment.
Among those arrested are 14 high-ranking police officers, Hürriyet Daily News reports.
Some of them were involved in the corruption investigations against government officials, including four government ministers last December.
In July, a number of Turkish police officers were arrested for allegedly forming an organized criminal group and tapping phone numbers.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan (who was Prime Minister at the time) described their actions as part of the activities led by the Islamist cleric Fethullah Gülen against him and other people in positions of power.
Not all children in Ukraine are returning to school.

This day is traditionally an important day for families, and like thousands of other Ukrainian parents, Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk brought his daughter to school.
There he informed waiting journalists that not all schools had reopened, but that he was determined to defend the country for future generations.
The September celebrations were not held in every school.
The sky is not peaceful everywhere over Ukraine.
We must fight for a peaceful sky.
The entire Ukraine, a huge united Ukrainian popular front, must fight for a peaceful sky.
Oleksandr Pastukhov, the principal of the school in Sloviansk that Yatsenyuk's daughter attends, spoke in Russian.
We hope that peace will finally reign here again and that the children will receive an education that will be useful to them in later life.
The first day of the new school year is traditionally celebrated, with children wearing embroidered shirts, holding balloons, and giving flowers to their teachers.
With Rona Fairhead, the BBC may have found the great director it needs.
She arrives with a proud train of glory from the banking world, media management, and the inner circle of the Tory party.
And she has firsthand experience.
Her career began at the global management consulting firm Bain & Co., after which she moved to Morgan Stanley, Bombardier, ICI, and the media world of Pearson.
She was chief executive of the Financial Times for seven years and resigned when the top job at parent company Pearson went to a younger male colleague.
Her severance payment was allegedly almost £1 million.
Their political ranking is also solid.
She was recommended to David Cameron by Lord Browne, the former chairman of BP, when he was looking for more private sector expertise in Whitehall: she became an advisor to the Cabinet.
Her husband is a former Tory councillor.
As early as May, I described the chairman's task as a poisoned chalice.
Not only does the BBC stand as a huge and complex entity at the heart of public life, but there is also an internal paradox in its structure.
Trust works in two directions: inwards, towards the top tier of BBC management, but also outwards, as a voice of public concern and unease when things go wrong.
This creates a near-unassailable duopoly that demands a complete and comprehensive reform.
But what newly arrived chairperson would risk running, attacking everything, and dismantling an institution as complex as a Chinese dynasty, while perhaps costing themselves their job in the process?
It is a difficult task.
And as if that weren't enough, many are also interested in seeing the BBC diminished - power, money, and status outdated.
While the competition is closing in and new technologies threaten old, comfortable certainties, the upcoming negotiation of the BBC's license fees is fraught with particular dangers.
For the modest sum of £145.50 per year, the British public buys itself into arguably the world's largest media company.
The BBC tells a good story: it says it reaches 96 percent of all households and costs each one only 40 pence per day.
And apparently the BBC is climbing back up the popularity scale: 53 percent support it today, compared to 31 percent 10 years ago.
Viewing and usage habits for the BBC have changed: I get news headlines on my mobile phone these days and watch missed programmes later on my iPlayer.
But it remains a much-loved and considerable institution.
She needs a considerable chairperson - I hope she's found one.
Perry from Texas says disparaging tweet was not authorized.

A tweet from the official account of Texas Republican Governor Rick Perry on Sunday contained a derogatory remark about the Democratic district attorney at the center of a criminal indictment against him for abuse of power.
The tweet was later deleted and replaced with another from Perry's account, which denied the previous one.
A tweet has just been sent from my account that was not authorized by me.
"I do not endorse the tweet and have deleted it," the later message said.
Perry's employees did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
Although the tweets came from Perry's official account, it wasn't clear who was actually operating the feed.
The earlier tweet painted an unflattering picture of Travis County District Attorney Rosemary Lehmberg, who was convicted of drunk driving in April 2013.
Perry vetoed funding for her office when she refused to resign, leading to an indictment of Perry—a possible 2016 presidential candidate—by a grand jury this month in Austin.
The tweet reads: "I don't always drive drunk at three times the legal limit... but when I do, I sue Governor Perry for letting it slip."
I am the drunkest Democrat in Texas.
Lehmberg's office was not tasked with leading the grand jury investigation against Perry.
This was led by Michael McCrum, a special prosecutor from San Antonio, who was selected by a Republican judge.
Perry pleaded not guilty and called the charges a political stunt.

His high-powered legal team asked the judge overseeing the case to dismiss the charges, arguing that the law used to prosecute the longest-serving governor in Texas history is unconstitutionally vague.
Perry stopped $7.5 million in state funding to the state's Public Integrity Unit — which is based in Travis County and investigates state corruption cases in Texas — when Lehmberg refused to resign.
This veto led to a public complaint from a left-leaning watchdog group.
Perry's official user account is frequently updated - and sometimes famous.

After finishing fifth in the Iowa caucuses during his 2012 presidential bid, Perry addressed speculation that he would quit by tweeting a photo of himself jogging near a lake, with the caption "South Carolina, we're coming!"
Berkeley declares housing market "normal" again.
One of London's most prominent property developers pointed out that the housing market in southeast England had "returned" to normal levels.

Homes in the capital were highly sought after and subject to enormous price increases, which prompted the Bank of England to set limits on mortgage lending in June due to widespread fears of a credit bubble.

Tony Pidgley, founder and chairman of upmarket housebuilder Berkeley, said on Monday: "Since the start of the current financial year, the market has returned to normal transaction levels from the peak of 2013," adding that this provided a "stable operating environment".
The London property market held up well during the downturn as foreign buyers flocked to the capital.
According to information from the land registry office, prices in the urban area jumped by 18.5 percent in the past year alone, far more than the average increase in England and Wales overall.
The average sale prices for Berkeley's private, affordable, and student offerings rose by about a fifth in the past year and were around £423,000 at the end of April.

However, a stronger pound has made London property less attractive to foreign buyers in recent months – some of whom have also been deterred by the introduction of new property taxes and political rhetoric around a potential "mansion tax" ahead of the general election next May.

London estate agent Foxtons warned last week that the April mortgage market report, which introduced tighter lending rules, would also lead to lower market growth in both property sales and prices in the second half of the year.
New data from the Bank of England on Monday show a decline in mortgage approvals in July, also suggesting that the housing market is cooling.
Hamptons International, another estate agency, revised its forecast for London house price growth in 2015 downwards to 3 percent, based on already weakening house price sentiment.
Transaction volumes in London's most expensive areas, such as Chelsea, Mayfair and Kensington, have now fallen by a quarter year on year, according to estate agent WA Ellis.
Nevertheless, the desire for home ownership in the capital is a boon for Berkeley, as the sums due on forward sales amount to more than £2.2 billion.
Mr. Pidgley added: "Demand for the right, well-planned product in the best locations has remained stable and, as a result, forward sales have also remained stable."
In June, the company reported that it had sold 3,742 new homes in the year to the end of April – almost a third more than the 2007 pre-crisis peak.
The annual pre-tax profit increased by 40 percent year-on-year to £280 million, revenue by 18 percent to £1.6 billion.
In a statement on Monday ahead of the company's annual meeting, Mr. Pidgley said that Berkeley's earnings for the current year were expected to be in line with current market expectations.
The analysts unanimously estimate the annual pre-tax profit at £450 million.
Berkeley shares were firm at £23.96 in London trading this afternoon.
Nude photos of Jennifer Lawrence published online by hackers.
Jennifer Lawrence's appearance at the 85th Academy Awards.
Nude photos of Oscar winner Jennifer Lawrence were published online by a hacker who claimed to have a "master list" of pictures of 100 other starlets.
A representative for the "Hunger Games" star confirmed that the photos of Lawrence were real and accused the hacker of a "flagrant violation of privacy."

Let's nip this in the bud. *Pun intended*.
Buzzfeed reported late Sunday that a spokesperson for pop star Ariana Grande denied the authenticity of alleged photos of her.
Exclusive excerpt from Howard Jacobson's highly praised new novel about love and the letter "J".
They dissolved, that was the best way to describe it, they slowly disintegrated like a cardboard box left out in the rain.
Occasionally a woman would tell him he was too serious, demanding, intense, distant, and perhaps a bit grumpy.
And then shook his hand.
Grumpy he knew.. / He knew grumpy..
He was prickly, like a hedgehog, yes...

The latest casualty of this prickliness was a budding affair, which had promised more relief from the lonely boredom of his life than usual, and might even have brought him a certain degree of contentment.
Ailinn Solomons was a tremblingly delicate beauty with untamed hair and a fluttering heart from a village on the North Island that was even more remote and rugged than Port Reuben.
She had come south with an older companion, whom Kevern took to be her aunt, and who had inherited a plot of land in a humid but paradisiacal valley aptly named Paradise Valley.
For several years, nobody had lived in the house.

The pipes were leaking, there were still spiders in the bathrooms, slugs had left their trails on all the windows and seemed to think they owned the place, and the garden was overgrown with weeds that looked like giant cabbages.
It was like a house from a fairy tale, both menacing and alluring, a garden full of secrets.
Author portrait: Howard Jacobson, whose novel "J" is longlisted for the 2014 Man Booker Prize.
The shortlist will be announced next week.

Kevern and Ailinn had been sitting hand-in-hand on the broken deck chairs in the tall grass, enjoying an unusually warm spring afternoon.  Both had absentmindedly plugged into the service console that supplied the land with calming music and soothing news, when the sight of their crossed brown legs reminded him of an old song by a long-forgotten black entertainer, whom his father used to listen to with the blinds drawn.
Your feet are too big.
Because of their inherent aggressiveness, songs of this kind were no longer played on the console.

Lesotho military member says no coup is planned; Prime Minister remains in South Africa.
Official military representatives in Lesotho denied plotting a coup to overthrow the government and said they were acting against police officers accused of arming political fanatics.
Prime Minister Thomas Thabane fled the country and said that the country's army had surrounded his official residence and occupied government buildings in the capital, Maseru.
The Prime Minister took his family to neighboring South Africa after reporting assassination threats.

Military spokesperson Major Ntlele Ntoi said that there was de facto no coup d'état, but that the military was responding to the threat of "political fanatics" whose arming by the police was imminent.

"What happened this morning was that the Lesotho Defence Force staff acted after receiving several intelligence reports that within the police force there were some elements acting, who actually wanted to arm some of the political, partisan young fanatics who were on the verge of causing havoc," he told Voice of America.
South African government spokesperson Clayson Monyela said the military action gave the impression of a coup.
"Even though no one has claimed to have seized the government by force, all reports on the matter agree that the Lesotho Defence Force's activities so far show signs of a coup d'état," he said.
Lesotho military spokesmen said on Sunday that soldiers were returning to their barracks and the situation in the capital was calm.
In the meantime, Deputy Prime Minister Mothetjoa Metsing will take over the government during Thabane's absence.
Thabane stated that he believes he was targeted because of his attempt to fight corruption in the country.
There has been great tension in Lesotho since June after Thabane suspended parliamentary sessions due to disputes within his unity government.
He said his actions hadn't undermined the government, despite accusations to the contrary.
Eurozone production at a 13-month low.
The rise in eurozone factory output slowed to its lowest point in 13 months in August, according to a closely watched survey.
The final Markit Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 50.7 in August, down from 51.8 in July.
A value above 50 indicates expansion.
New orders declined and factories experienced slumps amid rising tensions between the EU and Russia over Ukraine.
The figures arrive before the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting on Thursday.
The markets expect the bank to have a clear plan for dealing with a hesitant recovery of the Eurozone as well as for the looming deflation with an inflation rate of only 0.3%.

There is speculation that the head of the ECB, Mario Draghi, could give further details this week on whether he is considering quantitative easing for the Eurozone, similar to that undertaken by the UK and the US during the financial crisis.

"Although small growth is better than no growth at all, the dampening effects of rising economic and geopolitical uncertainties have become more apparent for manufacturers," said Rob Dobson, senior economist at Markit.
The factory PMI for Germany, Russia's largest trading partner in the EU, fell to its lowest level in 11 months at 51.4.
Meanwhile, in the bloc's second-largest economy, France, the PMI fell to 46.9.
France remains a cause for concern, as does Italy's decline from solid expansion to stagnation.
Indications that growth incentives are no longer working in the key industrial engine of Germany, as well as in Spain and the Netherlands, are also not reassuring," said Mr. Dobson.
The decline in industry is likely to fuel the fire of analysts who expect further monetary or fiscal stimulus.
Positive news came from the Republic of Ireland, where the PMI rose to 57.3, its highest level since the end of 1999.

Howard Archer, chief economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "The best that can be said for the eurozone manufacturing purchasing managers' index for August is that it still shows the sector expanding."

He added: "Producers in the eurozone are obviously finding life quite difficult at the moment, as the current heightened geopolitical tensions - especially with regard to Russia and Ukraine - are adding to uncertainties in what are already challenging conditions in many countries."
These increased uncertainties have clearly impacted the economy – especially consumer confidence – and will likely lead to some orders being delayed or even cancelled, particularly large orders.
He said that it was "increasingly likely" that the ECB would eventually have to initiate some form of QE, "although we suspect that this will be limited."
The hellish decade of the Beslan survivors: Ten years have passed since the horrific school siege, how the children caught up in it still suffer today.
Ten years ago, over 1,000 people were taken hostage by Chechen militants in a school in Beslan, southern Russia.

We returned to Beslan to find some of the victims who had escaped death in the classroom atrocity.
Exactly a decade after the horrific siege of the Beslan school, in which 334 people died, including 186 children, the heroic survivors warned last night of a new apocalypse in Ukraine.

4 Tips for Better Underwater Photos and Videos
If you like to take photos or videos underwater, there is a selection of devices.
The most affordable option is a waterproof point-and-shoot, like the Nikon Coolpix AW120 or an action cam like the GoPro Hero3+ Silver Edition, both of which are available for around $300.
I took these photos at a family gathering with several cameras, all of which are available for under $350.
Regardless of the equipment, there are a few rules for the best results.
Check your equipment twice.
Even if you have a waterproof camera, make sure that the battery compartment and other compartments are tightly closed.
Set your camera to the photos or videos you want to take.
Some cameras and camcorders have scene and recording modes that optimize exposure time for dim underwater conditions.
And before you jump in, check to what depth your equipment is functional.
Some cameras are only approved for up to 5 feet, others up to 50 or 60 feet.
Search our buying guide and reviews for digital cameras for both conventional and waterproof models.
Take multiple shots - because many won't work.
Point-and-shoot cameras have an LCD that you can use to compose images; action cams usually don't.
Even if you have an LCD, it's difficult to see it underwater, and getting the right picture settings is a matter of luck.
So take lots of pictures/shots.
